review.title: Inferring Strategies for Sentence Ordering in Multidocument News Summarization
review.abstract: The problem of organizing information for multidocument summarization so that the generated summary is coherent has received relatively little attention. While sentence ordering for single document summarization can be determined from the ordering of sentences in the input article, this is not the case for multidocument summarization where summary sentences may be drawn from different input articles. In this paper, we propose a methodology for studying the properties of ordering information in the news genre and describe experiments done on a corpus of multiple acceptable orderings we developed for the task. Based on these experiments, we implemented a strategy for ordering information that combines constraints from chronological order of events and topical relatedness. Evaluation of our augmented algorithm shows a significant improvement of the ordering over two baseline strategies.

sections.heading: 2. Impact of Ordering on the Overall Quality of a Summary
sections.text: Although the problem of ordering information for multipliers has attracted relatively little attention, we hypothesize that a good order is crucial to producing quality summaries. Ideally, the consensus architecture of the state of things that are summarized consists of a content selection module in which the relevant information is extracted and a regeneration module in which the information is converted into a flowing text. Ideally, the regeneration architecture includes devices that perform a surface repair of the text by making a summary or selecting the corresponding lexical paraphrases. Our contention in this paper is that the multiplication architecture needs an explicit ordering component. If two pieces of information are summarized but not summarized, then one more surface mark should be selected.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Evaluation
sections.text: Using the same methodology we used to evaluate the MO algorithm, we asked three human judges (without ourselves) to compile grade 25 summaries that the system applied to the same set of input texts using the CO algorithm. Results are shown in Figure 13: ten summaries were rated as bad, eight were rated as fair, and seven were rated as good. Our first suspicion was that our approach deviated too much from the real chronological order of events and thus diminished the quality of the sentence order. To confirm this hypothesis, we identified sentences that broke the original chronological order and restored the order manually. Interestingly, the shifted sentences were mainly background information.

sections.heading: 5. Improving the Ordering: Experiments and Analysis
sections.text: In the previous section, we have shown that the use of naive ordering algorithms does not produce satisfactory orders. In this section, we will investigate by experimenting with people how to identify order patterns that can improve the algorithm.

sections.heading: 5.2 Analysis
sections.text: The various alternative orders created for a single summary have things in common. We noticed that within the multiple orders of a sentence, some sentences always appear together; they do not appear in the same order from one order to the next, but they share an adjacent relationship. From now on, we refer to them as blocks. For each sentence, we identify blocks by automatically grouping sentences across orders. We use the average number of sentences that separate them across all orders as a distance measurement between two sentences. In Figure 10, for example, the distance between sentences D and G is 2. The blocks that are identified by clustering are: sentences B, D, G and I; sentences A and J; sentences C and F; and sentences E and H. We observed that all blocks in the experiment correspond to clusters of topically related sentences. These blocks form units of text that have to do with the same theme. In other words, all valid orders contain blocks that are contiguous.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we examined the arrangement of constraints in the majority of documents in the news genre. We evaluated two alternative constraints (CO) and majority orders (MO). Our experiments show that MO performs well only if all input texts follow a similar organization. In the areas where these constraints apply, MO would be an appropriate and highly effective strategy. But in the news genre, we cannot make this assumption. So it is not an appropriate solution. Chronological order (CO) can provide an acceptable solution for many cases, but it is not sufficient if the summaries contain information that is not based on events.

However, using a modified version of topological sort provides us with an approximate solution. For each node, we assign a weight equal to the sum of the weights of its outgoing edges minus the sum of the weights of its incoming edges. We first pick up the node with maximum weight, ordering it ahead of the other nodes, delete it and its outgoing edges from the precedence graph and update properly the weights of the remaining nodes in the graph.
